-C.value: try { Use-Icinga -Minimal; } catch { Write-Output 'The Icinga PowerShell Framework is either not installed on the system or not configured properly. Please check https://icinga.com/docs/windows for further details'; Write-Output "Error: $$($$_.Exception.Message)Components:`r`n$$( Get-Module -ListAvailable "icinga-powershell-*" )`r`nModule-Path:`r`n$$($$Env:PSModulePath)"; exit 3; }; Exit-IcingaExecutePlugin -Command 'Invoke-IcingaCheckCertificate'

3.description:
Used to switch on trusted behavior. Whether to check, If the certificate is trusted by the system root.
Will return Critical in case of untrusted.

Note: it is currently required that the root and intermediate CA is known and trusted by the local system.
3.caption: Trusted

5.description:
Used to specify a Warning range for the end date of an certificate. In this case a string.
Allowed units include: ms, s, m, h, d, w, M, y
5.caption: WarningEnd

12.description: Used to specify an array of certificate names of certificate files to check. Use with CertPaths.
12.caption: CertName

10.description: Used to specify which path within the CertStore should be checked.
10.caption: CertStorePath

2.description: Change the value your defined threshold checks against from the current value to a collected time threshold of the Icinga for Windows daemon, as described here: https://icinga.com/docs/icinga-for-windows/latest/doc/service/10-Register-Service-Checks/ An example for this argument would be 1m or 15m which will use the average of 1m or 15m for monitoring.
2.caption: ThresholdInterval

8.description: Used to specify an array of Thumbprints, which are used to determine what certificate to check, within the CertStore.
8.caption: CertThumbprint

11.description: Used to specify an array of paths on your system, where certificate files are. Use with CertName.
11.caption: CertPaths

9.description: Used to specify an array of Subjects, which are used to determine what certificate to check, within the CertStore.
9.caption: CertSubject

14.description: Will return `OK` instead of `UNKNOWN`, in case no certificates for the given filter and path were found
14.caption: IgnoreEmpty

7.description: Used to specify which CertStore to check. Valid choices are '*', 'LocalMachine', 'CurrentUser'
7.caption: CertStore

15.description:
Changes the behavior of the plugin output which check states are printed:
0 (default): Only service checks/packages with state not OK will be printed
1: Only services with not OK will be printed including OK checks of affected check packages including Package config
2: Everything will be printed regardless of the check state
3: Identical to Verbose 2, but prints in addition the check package configuration e.g (All must be [OK])
15.caption: Verbosity

6.description:
Used to specify a Critical range for the end date of an certificate. In this case a string.
Allowed units include: ms, s, m, h, d, w, M, y
6.caption: CriticalEnd

4.description:
Used to specify a date. The start date of the certificate has to be past the date specified, otherwise the check results in critical. Use carefully.
Use format like: 'yyyy-MM-dd'
4.caption: CriticalStart

13.description: Includes sub-directories and entries while looking for certificates on a given path
13.caption: Recurse
